Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Processing code-switching in bilinguals: effects of language use and semantic expectancy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most bilinguals code-switch to some extent, that is, they move from one language to the other within the same utterance. The United States has an increasingly heterogeneous population, which includes a growing number of bilingual immigrants who use both English and their other language when communicating among each other. Code switching is often stigmatized and sometimes perceived as a deficiency in learning languages. However, code switching often occurs among highly-proficient bilinguals who are perfectly able to speak each language separately. Instead of condemning code switching, code switching should be seen as a cognitive tour de force. Investigating how bilingual speakers organize and select among the languages they know, how they process mixed languages, and what factors determine this, will therefore provide insight in human cognitive and social functioning in general.

Previous psycholinguistic research on language switching has reported that switching between languages is difficult or costly. These studies have mostly ignored the bilingual's daily switching habits. The current study challenges the view that code switching is always costly by testing language users who code-switch on a regular basis, using multilinguals in Algeria as a case study. This population switches frequently between Algerian-Arabic and French; however, switching between Standard-Arabic and French is not common. This makes this population ideal to investigate whether the habit of switching between a pair of languages rather than another pair affects the expectation of switching, thus potentially minimizing or even eliminating the costs. In particular, the proposed research will test to what extent the switch costs depend on (1) the semantic expectancy of a particular word in a sentence; and (2) the daily frequency of switching between certain language pairs compared to others. Importantly, the current study will use spoken language, which is more naturalistic than the reading-only paradigms used in previous studies. In addition, the outcomes of the listening study will be related to the results from a survey on the language habits of the bilinguals in the study and their perception of and attitudes towards code switching. Findings from this project will therefore provide insight into the linguistic and non-linguistic factors that drive code-switching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merits

An important question in language science is how speakers of languages store, organize and select words that would be used later during language production or comprehension. Investigating language processing in speakers of two or more languages can reveal important insights on how the human mind deals with competing language information. In fact, in some bilingual communities, speakers alternate between their languages (also known as "code-switch") even within the same sentence. Therefore, studying language switching in these particular speakers may help us understand the process of word selection and untangle some of the above questions.

The research supported by this award used bilingual speakers who code-switch to study the difficulty involved in switching between languages. In particular, it tested whether switching and word selection can be made easier when the words that indicate the switch are partly shared between the languages the bilingual speaks. In addition, it examined whether the way bilinguals use their languages in everyday interactions affects how bilinguals expect a switch to the other language during listening. We found that while it does not make a difference for bilinguals who are proficient in both languages whether the word is shared or not, the use of shared words during code-switching makes switching and word recognition easier for bilinguals who are less proficient in their second language. This suggests that although bilinguals of different degrees of proficiency may code-switch, lower proficiency bilinguals may use code-switching as a strategy to overcome the cross-language interaction during word selection. Additionally, the selection of a switched word is easier when the word is part of the languages that the bilinguals habitually use in everyday communication. This means that speakers understand better those language constructions that resemble the ones regularly found in speech.

Broader impacts

Given the increased demand for being able to communicate in more than one language, the number of bilingual speakers in the world is constantly on the rise. It is then important to understand how multiple languages interact in the human mind. In some communities, mixing languages in the same speech is stigmatized as it is viewed as a sign of failure to learn either language. On the contrary, code-switching may be taken as a sign of competence in dealing with the cross-language interaction that arises when bilinguals produce or comprehend language when they target fluency. This strategy in overcoming the competition for word selection that is due to the cross-language interaction helps some individuals to communicate more efficiently.
